title: 2020 BMW X3 M Competition review: fun for five minutes, but pointless thereafter
text:
One little prod of the throttle; a simple flexing of the right foot. That’s all it takes in the BMW X3 M Competition to invoke an involuntary chortle. The sheer silliness of it all; a car better known for carting well-to-do children to good schools and back home again, with 503bhp. Five hundred and three!

That’s as much as you’ll find in the latest Aston Martin Vantage. More, even, than you’d have found in a Ferrari F40 in the prime of its life. Yet this is no lithe, low sports car. This is a big, tall SUV, one with five proper seats and four-wheel drive and – in theory, at least – the ability to crawl its way up a muddy slope.

Of course, few BMW X3s will see such a slope in their lifetimes,...
